glsa.title: Git: Multiple vulnerabilities
glsa.synopsis: Git contains multiple vulnerabilities that allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code.

background.p: Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

description.p: Git is vulnerable to the remote execution of arbitrary code by cloning repositories with large filenames or a large number of nested trees. Additionally, some protocols within Git, such as git-remote-ext, can execute arbitrary code found within URLs. These URLs that submodules use may come from arbitrary sources (e.g., .gitmodules files in a remote repository), and can effect those who enable recursive fetch. Restrict the allowed protocols to well known and safe ones.

impact.p: Remote attackers could execute arbitrary code on both client and server.

workaround.p: There is no known workaround at this time.

resolution.p: All Git users should upgrade to the latest version:

references.uri: Buffer overflow in all git versions before 2.7.1
